titleStmt.title: Critical Apparatus for Lectio 7, de Fide
titleStmt.author: Petrus Plaoul

edition.title: Critical Apparatus for Lectio 7, de Fide

availability.p: Published under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 3.0 License

app.note: It seems like the sense could go either way. The Vatican reading, however, would suggest that the priest forces the simple person to be an idolater, whereas the reading of R, SV, S suggest that the "strictly speaking" (simpliciter) it is the priest who is the idolater.
We select the more explicit reading here

Despite its lack of support "permit" seems to make more sense here than "promise." We read this as saying "they [the simple] have that which is contained under some liknesses as an object of adoration. And this 'is permitted' to them because if they were required/induced to believe conditionally, then they would hesitate on account of this, and their devotion would be lessened."
We include "ipsi" as the more explicit rendering

Both R and V are quite clear about "difficiliores" here. SV is less clear, but could easily be "difficiliores." S is more difficult to render as "difficiliores" as it appears to be an identical abbreviation of the previous use (three words prior) of "difficultates"

app.lem: Et ista ratio est maximae apparentiae unde arguebatur sic, ponatur quod ante incarnationem aliquis assensit isti mediante habitu fide, 'Christus incarnabitur', et quod ille assensus continuetur usque ad instans incarnationis

app.note: We understand "discutere" as "to discuss" or "to examine" which seems to fit the sense best.
We see the best reading as: "to know the time of the coming of Christ"

app.lem: hoc disiunctum Christus incarnabitur vel est incarnatus vel incarnatur quam magis docti in Scripturis, quia magis docti non obligabantur ad credendum

app.note: While the difference seems slight, we chose to avoid the use of "discurrere" in R and SV because we do not it is meaning as clearly coincides with the sense reflect in the other words used, i.e. "discernere," "distinguere," and "discutere" (above).

app.lem: fidei unde in eadem instanti, scilicet, in instanti incarnationis desinit esse assensus fidei respectu huius 'Christus incarnabitur,' et incepit esse assensus huius de praesenti 'Christus incarnabitur,' ita quod illud instans incarnationis fuit instans primum non esse

Alia propositio in eodem instanti in quo incepit esse assensus fidei respectu huius de praesenti 'Christus incarnatur' in eodem instanti incepit esse assensus fidei respectu huius de praeterito 'Christus incarnabatur'
non fuit et immediate ante illud instans fuit. Assensus etiam de praesenti respectu huius 'Christus incarnatur' in illo instanti desivit esse, quia in illo
quia in illo fuit et in nullo ante fuit, ergo in illo incepti. Sequitur ulterius quod assensus respectu huius verbi de praesenti 'Christus incarnatur' proportionaliter et
quia, in toto tempore in quo poterant sufficienter ex Scripturis distinguere de adventu Christi, tenebantur huic assentire de futuro 'Christus incarnabitur'
et post instans incarnationis inclinabat ad credendum quod
revelationes a Spiritu Sancto quas formabant ex proprio capite et non poterant ponere differentiam inter
ita fides pro tunc inclinabat ad assentiendum isti 'Christus incarnabitur'
huius: 'Christus incarnatur' ante Christi incarnationem, non fuisset assensus fidei, sed assensus

non habet necessariam istam habitudinem sic esse sicut significat, nec dependent ab obiecto, sicut satis dictum est, et sic si Christus non incarnetur, assensus ille numquam potuit fore assensus huius â€œChristus incarnabitur,â€ sed erit assensus sui oppositi, et causa est iam dicta, quia
humanitus assentire vel dissentire, quia utraque pars esset illicita ut satis probatum est, quia si assentiret veritati peccaret
incidit in peccatum praesumptionis, si falsitati assentiebat
Vel aliter dicitur quod Abraham. . . immolatur non sibi

app.rdg: fides ad producendum assensum falsum non est ad propositum
